item.dc:creator: @aikon aikon
item.description:
@aikon wrote:

easiest way to do it, put in test values of X that will cancel out as many terms as possible… we use this for partial fractions in my Differential equations course, by FAR the fastest way to do it… you can do it by solving the 3 equations and whatnot, but its a pain in the ass…
so x=5 cancels out the last two terms leaving you with (5)(5) + 31 == A(7)(6) A=4/3.

x=-2 cancels out the first and last term, leaving you with 5(-2) + 31 == B(-3)(-7) b==-1
now just substitue a=4/3 and b==-1 into your original equation and solve for the necessary values of C. so from the x^2 terms you get that a+b+c ==0, so 4/3 - 1 + c == 0
c = -1/3.

if your looking to do something with division of polynomials, try using synthetic division.

ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + d and you want to divide q +wx
put it into a table like this

                                        w | a        b        c         d

now drop the first value a a

w*a and subtract it from b. w | a b c d
-wa
then take that answer, multiply it by your w again, and repeat until you get to the end. what you get in the last box is your remainder, and all of the other terms are x^(n-1). meaning that your first digit on the left side corresponds to the x^2 now, second to x^1, and so on…

idiot[br][size=1]Posted at: November 03, 2006, 05:34:01 AM[/size][hr]so we have this equation:

5x + 31= A(x+2)(x-1) + B(x-1)(x-5) + C(x-5)(x+2)

for us to find the values we need to make some of the others dissapear (WTF EHH??),
do this by making them equal to 0.

so to Find A,
i can see that (x-5) is missing, so i shall use x = 5 in this case

25 + 31 = A(7)(4) + B(4)(0) + C(0)(7)
56 = 28A + 0 + 0
A = 56/28
A = 2

To Find B
i can see that (x+2) is missing, so i shall use x = -2 in this case

-10 + 31 = A(0)(-3) + B(-3)(-7) + C(-7)(0)
21 = 0 + 21B + 0 (Minus * Minus = plus)
B = 21/21
B = 1

To Find C
i can see that (x+2) is missing, so i shall use x = 1 in this case

5 + 31 = A(3)(0) + B(0)(-4) + C(-4)(3)
36 = 0 + 0 - 12C
C = 16/-12
C = -3

Zym @ SYI Solved This One

I got bored thought id look at the second one, it does work. Its a bit simpler

Assuming you understand the factor theorm right then f(1) = 6 and f(-2) = -24

That bit im not going to explain because the proof is long and i cant remember it, it ll be in your books somewhere.

But then f(1) = 1 + a + b - 2 + 8
f(1) = 7 + a + b
And f(1) = 6 (from the theorem) so 7 + a + b = 6

And also f(-2) = 16 - 8a + 4b + 12
f(-2) = 28 - 8a + 4b
And f(-2) = -24 (from the theorem) so 28 - 8a + 4b = -24
-8a + 4b = -52
-2a + b = -13

Thats just algebra, should be simple enough, but leaves us with the 2 equations

-2a + b = -13 and 7 + a + b = 6
So if we rearrange them to make b equals…
b = 2a - 13 and b = -1 - a

So now we know both equations are equal to b, so they must both be the same so
2a - 13 = -1 - a
Rearrange to get 3a = 12, and then a = 4.

And go back to b = -1 - a, and now we know a = 4 so b = -1 - 4 so b = 5.

Theres your too answers. Sorry if i went into too much detail, or not enough, i dont know your level at all so i just showed my steps but didnt explain them.

If anything doesnt make sense then ask.

Ima have another look at the first question in a second, i hate it when i get questions i cant solve :S
